articles.headline: U.S. House Committee Plans Hearing on Toyota Recall
articles.snippet: The committee wants Toyota and the highway safety agency to discuss when they first learned about potential safety defects and what they have done to resolve them.
articles.abstract: The committee wants Toyota and the highway safety agency to discuss when they first learned about potential safety defects and what they have done to resolve them.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Toyota faced heightened scrutiny on Thursday over problems with the accelerator pedals on its vehicles, as a House committee scheduled Congressional hearings into the matter and its recalls expanded to Europe and China.

articles.headline: Senate, Weakly, Backs New Term for Bernanke
articles.snippet: The Senate vote, 70-30, was a victory for President Obama, but signaled how much the Fed has become the object of outrage over high unemployment and bailouts.
articles.abstract: The Senate vote, 70-30, was a victory for President Obama, but signaled how much the Fed has become the object of outrage over high unemployment and bailouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Senate gave Ben S. Bernanke a second four-year term as the head of the Federal Reserve on Thursday after critics excoriated the central bank’s conduct in the years leading up to the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Doctor’s Killer Puts Abortion on the Stand
articles.snippet: Scott Roeder’s lawyers want jurors to consider his opposition to abortion as a valid motive for murder.
articles.abstract: Scott Roeder’s lawyers want jurors to consider his opposition to abortion as a valid motive for murder.
articles.lead_paragraph: WICHITA, Kan.  Scott Roeder, the man charged with murder in the shooting of George R. Tiller, one of the few doctors in the country to perform late-term abortions, took the witness stand in his own defense on Thursday, and said that, yes, he did it.

articles.headline: In the Packaging of Loans, a Bust With Precedent
articles.snippet: Though few people remember it, an earlier wave of private securitizations altered the real estate landscape, particularly in New York and other big U.S. cities.
articles.abstract: Though few people remember it, an earlier wave of private securitizations altered the real estate landscape, particularly in New York and other big U.S. cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Real estate securitization was one of the great innovations in finance in the last quarter-century. In an unprecedented way, it allowed vast sums of money to go into the real estate market from people who traditionally did not take part in it.

articles.headline: Firm Brings Gene Tests to Masses
articles.snippet: A Silicon Valley start-up says it can help eradicate more than 100 diseases by allowing couples to avoid having children with the carrier genes.
articles.abstract: A Silicon Valley start-up says it can help eradicate more than 100 diseases by allowing couples to avoid having children with the carrier genes.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDWOOD CITY, Calif.  The new movie “Extraordinary Measures” is based on the true story of a father who starts a company to develop a treatment for the rare genetic disease threatening to kill two of his children before they turn 10.

articles.headline: Health Bill Stalled, Obama Juggles an Altered Agenda
articles.snippet: Democrats will try to act first on jobs, deficits and bank regulation before returning to the president’s top priority from last year, an overhaul of health care.
articles.abstract: Democrats will try to act first on jobs, deficits and bank regulation before returning to the president’s top priority from last year, an overhaul of health care.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The White House on Thursday signaled the outlines of its strategy for breaking the partisan logjam holding up President Obama’s agenda, saying Democrats would move quickly to underline their commitment to fixing the broken economy and to build an election-year case against Republicans if they do not cooperate.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Administration Considers Moving Site of 9/11 Trial
articles.snippet: The Justice Department, facing mounting pressure from New York politicians, is exploring contingency sites for the trial of alleged terrorist conspirators.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department, facing mounting pressure from New York politicians, is exploring contingency sites for the trial of alleged terrorist conspirators.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Facing mounting pressure from New York politicians concerned about costs and security, the Obama administration on Thursday began considering moving the trial of the chief organizer of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks out of Manhattan, administration officials said.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Benjamin Weiser

articles.headline: Europe Weighs Possibility of Debt Default in Greece
articles.snippet: After a decade of debt-fueled profligacy, Greece is confronting what amounts to a run on the bank, and European leaders are quietly weighing what to do.
articles.abstract: After a decade of debt-fueled profligacy, Greece is confronting what amounts to a run on the bank, and European leaders are quietly weighing what to do.
articles.lead_paragraph: European leaders are quietly considering whether to come to the aid of their troubled neighbor Greece amid fears that the nation might default on its debts and unleash another round of financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Matthew Saltmarsh

articles.headline: Obama Sets Ambitious Export Goal
articles.snippet: Since the Obama administration has not yet clearly articulated a trade policy, his pledge on Wednesday night to double exports in five years was greeted with incredulity.
articles.abstract: Since the Obama administration has not yet clearly articulated a trade policy, his pledge on Wednesday night to double exports in five years was greeted with incredulity.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In promising Wednesday night to double the United States’ export growth over the next five years, President Obama set an ambitious goal for American trade policy that, he said, could create two million jobs.

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Grew at Vigorous Pace in Last Quarter
articles.snippet: The economy grew at an annualized rate of 5.7% in the quarter, faster than expected, but economists still worried about the sluggish job market.
articles.abstract: The economy grew at an annualized rate of 5.7% in the quarter, faster than expected, but economists still worried about the sluggish job market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States economy grew at its fastest pace in more than six years at the end of 2009, even as businesses resisted hiring and continued to do more with less.
